 I can get behind about 90% of that. I don't think she disrespects her son intentionally but I do agree she's riding on the coattails of his death and is really enjoying the spotlight. So, in that regard, perhaps, yes.
 
 But you need to know that there are many who feel this Iraq war was unnecessary. In fact, we are undoubtedly convinced. It is what it is.
 What to do about it now? How do we close Pandora's box? That's another talk show. 
 
 Also, a LOT of people here and fighting in Iraq believe that we could care less that our soldiers/children/fathers/sond/daughters are stuck in a sand hell, fighting and dying for causes only known to the puppetmasters. I would imagine that knowing someone cares enough to raise a stink about it at the homefront gives them solace. Not ALL of us want them there. Some really do care.
 Yes, that 60+% of America who do not approve of what's going on over there will be heard even if the -40% disagrees. 
 
 Over 100,000 people showed up to protest the war last week in Washington. The counter demonstration supporting the war drew 400. Food for thought.
 
 But if Sheenan veers off course from the Iraq war, and starts trumpeting other liberal views and causes, then we can safely say that she is now a media puppet for the puppetmasters on the other side. Not much different from the ones that pulls your strings.
 
 You know, the Sunni's have the same trouble over in Iraq. They are a minority trying to dominate the majority. America won't stand for that. Get ready for more Cindy Sheenans.

Over 100,000 people showed up to protest the war last week in Washington. The counter demonstration supporting the war drew 400. Food for thought.

 While I don't neccesarily buy all the XXXX the government fed us at the beginning of this mess, I do support the fact that we need to stay and finish what we started. Funny thing is, I have never been to a pro-war rally or demonstration.
 
 But off the top of my head, I have a hard time remembering many pro-war demonstrations. I don't really see what reason a war supporter would have to go out and hold up signs shouting pro-war slogans. The pro-war crowd seems to be content with the current situation, so simply no reason to protest. And I doubt that the 400 war supporters who showed up were there to protest the war, as much as they were there to protest the anti-war crowd. 
 
 As far as the protesters, they certainly have every right to go out and protest all day long. I have no problem with them exercising their rights. It is the 2% lunatic fringe that bothers me, Cindy included.
